content:
Certainly, here is the complete table: | Stakeholders Title | Stakeholder Type | Potential Benefit/Harm | Indicators to Measure Impact | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Rural communities in the 100 villages | Individuals | Benefit: Improved access to clean water | 1. Increase in access to safe and clean water sources
2. Reduction in water-borne illnesses
3. Increased time for productive activities (such as education and employment) due to reduced time spent collecting water | | Local government and authorities | Government | Benefit: Improved public health and reduced burden on local resources | 1. Reduction in health care costs related to water-borne illnesses
2. Improved public satisfaction with the provision of water and sanitation services
3. Increased tax revenue due to improved economic activity in the region | | Water and sanitation organizations | Non-profit | Benefit: Improved access to clean water for rural communities | 1. Increased access to safe and clean water sources for rural communities
2. Reduction in water-borne illnesses in rural communities
3. Improved reputation and credibility of the organization | | Health care providers and facilities | Business/Non-profit | Benefit: Improved public health and reduced burden on local resources | 1. Reduction in cases of water-borne illnesses
2. Increase in patient satisfaction with health care services
3. Increased revenue due to reduced burden on resources | | Agricultural businesses and farmers | Business | Benefit: Improved access to water for irrigation and farming purposes | 1. Increase in crop yield and quality
2. Reduction in water-related crop losses
3. Increased revenue for agricultural businesses and farmers | | Women and children who collect water | Individuals | Benefit: Reduced time and effort spent on collecting water | 1. Reduction in time spent collecting water
2. Increase in time for education and employment
3. Improved health due to reduced physical strain from collecting water | | Schools and educational institutions | Non-profit | Benefit: Improved access to clean water for students and staff | 1. Increase in access to safe and clean water for students and staff
2. Reduction in water-borne illnesses among students and staff
3. Improved reputation of the school or institution | | Local businesses and industries | Business | Benefit: Improved access to water for industrial purposes | 1. Increase in production capacity
2. Reduction in water-related production losses
3. Increased revenue for local businesses and industries | | Landowners and residents who may be displaced | Individuals | Harm: Loss of property and displacement | 1. Number of people displaced
2. Adequacy of compensation and support for displaced individuals
3. Reduction in property values in the area | | Traditional water sources | N/A | Harm: Contamination or obsolescence of traditional water sources | 1. Reduction in water quality of traditional sources
2. Decrease in use of traditional water sources
3. Negative impact on local communities who rely on traditional sources for religious or cultural practices | | Environmental organizations | Non-profit | Harm: Potential environmental impacts of the project | 1. Reduction in water quality of surrounding environment
2. Negative impact on wildlife and their habitats
3. Reduction in public support for the organization | | Small-scale water vendors | Business | Harm: Loss of business due to the availability of running water | 1. Reduction in water sales
2. Decrease in revenue for small-scale water vendors
3. Loss of livelihood for small-scale water vendors |
